facts.text: Appellants carried on business in partnership as Ishwarsing Dhiansingh and owned two motor trucks: No. AWB 230 (V-8 Ford 1938 Model) and No. AWB 253 (Oldsmobile Model 1938).
On May 4, 1942, appellants entered into agreement hiring out trucks to respondent for imparting tuition to military personnel at Rs. 17 per day per truck, terminable on one month's notice.
Truck No. AWB 230 handed over to respondent on April 29, 1942; truck No. AWB 253 on May 4, 1942.
Respondent used AWB 230 from April 29, 1942 to July 31, 1942 except June 4-9, 1942; AWB 253 from May 4, 1942 to July 31, 1942 except June 1-9, 1942.
On June 29, 1942, respondent gave notice terminating agreement effective August 1, 1942, and asked appellants to remove trucks.
Appellant No. 1 attended Officer Commanding 4 T.T. Centre, Kamptee at 9 a.m. on August 1, 1942 to remove trucks, but not delivered by transport in-charge; letter sent same date to S.S.O., Kamptee.
Respondent neither returned trucks nor paid hire charges; claimed hire paid and trucks delivered to Surjan Singh, alleged partner of appellants.
Appellants denied Surjan Singh was partner; claimed hire money and return of trucks.

On August 4, 1942, appellants gave notice u/s 80 CPC claiming: (i) hire up to July 31, 1942 at Rs.17/day +6% interest; (ii) damages Rs.17/day/truck from Aug 1, 1942 till delivery; (iii) return of trucks or Rs.3,500 value.
Suit filed January 8, 1943 against respondent and Surjan Singh for above reliefs + future damages + costs; cause: failure to pay hire and non-delivery due to wrongful delivery to Surjan Singh.

Trial Court (Third Additional District Judge, Nagpur, July 7, 1944): Held respondent not justified in delivering to Surjan Singh; awarded Rs.2,380 rent + interest @6% from Aug 1, 1942 to Jan 7, 1943; Rs.3,500 value +6% interest as damages; no mesne profits; total Rs.6,032-4-0 + costs vs both defendants.

Appeal to Nagpur High Court (First Appeal No. 27 of 1944): Appellants claimed Rs.11,985 + higher truck value; valued appeal at Rs.5,953, paid court-fee; later paid additional Rs.1,279-11-0 on Rs.16,626.

High Court (April 7, 1948): Disallowed higher truck value (limited to Rs.3,500 per notice); damages for detention Aug 1, 1942 to July 7, 1944 at Rs.17/day fair for substantial portion; enhanced decree by Rs.5,953 (total further Rs.5,477 compensation); appeal allowed to that extent + costs.
Certificate u/s 110 CPC granted; appeal to Supreme Court.
Evidence showed truck prices appreciated ~100% by Feb 1, 1944; value Rs.7,000 total at decree date.

legal_issues.text: Rights and remedies of bailor when bailee fails to deliver goods on demand: wrongful conversion (trover) vs wrongful detention (detinue).
Measure of value in detinue: at date of tort/breach or date of judgment/verdict.
Damages for wrongful detention: quantum, e.g., hire rate for reasonable period.
Effect of s.80 CPC notice claiming Rs.3,500 value: bars higher claim at judgment date?

petitioner_arguments.text: Suit for wrongful detention (detinue); entitled to return of trucks or value at date of decree (Rs.7,000 each = Rs.14,000); plus damages @ Rs.17/day/truck from Aug 1, 1942 till decree date July 7, 1944.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Detinue: value at judgment date; election of remedy

petitioner_arguments.text: s.80 notice complied with; reserved right to claim excess value due to price rise by additional court-fee.

respondent_arguments.text: At worst, wrongful conversion from Aug 1, 1942; damages = price at conversion date + 6% interest; not more.
Even if detention, not more than price at trial decree + nominal damages till then; High Court award sufficient, appeal to be dismissed.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Damages for detention nominal unless special damage

court_reasoning.text: Bailor elects remedy: conversion or detention; bailee cannot dictate or take advantage of own wrong; appellants elected detinue, no delay/speculation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Plaintiff's election prevails; bailee cannot better position by wrongful delivery.

court_reasoning.text: In detinue (continuing wrong), alternative value assessed at judgment date, not tort date; evidence justifies Rs.7,000 total.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Value at verdict/judgment; distinguishes from conversion.

court_reasoning.text: s.80 notice strictly but sensibly construed; claimed then-value Rs.3,500 or delivery; suit reserves excess; no bar to appreciated value.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Common sense reading; no pedantic scrutiny.

court_reasoning.text: Damages for detention: reasonable hire rate (Rs.17/day/truck) for ~1 year commission (old trucks); total additional Rs.6,457 beyond High Court Rs.5,953.
court_reasoning.key_observation: User value even if owner couldn't hire every day; wrongdoer pays reasonable hire.

holdings.text: Bailor may elect detinue despite bailee's prior conversion; bailee cannot object.
In detinue, chattel value in alternative assessed at judgment date.
Damages for detention: reasonable hiring rate for period trucks would likely be used.
s.80 notice not bar to higher value at decree if sensibly read.

precedents_cited.relevance: Bailee cannot set up own wrongful act (non-delivery) as answer to detinue.
Bailor elects remedy; bailee cannot better position by parting with possession.
Detinue value at judgment date, not refusal; same whether converted or not.
Measure same in conversion/detinue if simple refusal; consider delay if prices rise.
Evolution of modern actions; conversion vs detention.

precedents_cited.case_name: Strand Electric Engineering Co. Ltd. v. [not specified]
precedents_cited.relevance: Damages for detention: reasonable hire even if no actual loss.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bhagchand Dagadusa v. Secretary of State
precedents_cited.relevance: s.80 strict compliance, but common sense.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Notice before suit against government; certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed: In addition to High Court enhanced decree, decreed Rs.3,500 (appreciated truck value) + 6% interest from July 7, 1944; Rs.6,457 additional damages for detention; additional proportionate costs in trial/High Court + Supreme Court costs; subject to additional court-fee.
outcome.relief_granted: Rs.3,500 value + interest; Rs.6,457 damages; costs.
outcome.costs: Additional proportionate costs in lower courts + costs of appeal.

key_quotes.text: "The defendant cannot be heard to say that the plaintiff knew or ought to have known of the conversion of the goods by him and therefore should pursue his remedy only in conversion. He cannot take advantage of his own wrong."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle allowing bailor's election of remedy.

key_quotes.text: "In detinue... the value of the goods to be paid by the defendants... must be assessed as at the date of the verdict or judgment... and not at that of the defendants' refusal."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Adopts Rosenthal: value at judgment in detinue.

key_quotes.text: "A wrongdoer who keeps the owner out of his... goods, must pay a fair rental value for [them], even though the owner would not have been able to use [them] himself."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Measure of detention damages: reasonable hire.
